column4: If it's always getting errors in the same spots, and not getting worse, you can tell the kernel not to use those blocks of memory with badram
so I should do the memtest again then? It got 2 errors in different spots. I heard the memtest should run for hours.
Thanks I'll do it again. How long should it run?
How much ram do you have?
I have 1.2 or 1.3 G of ram.

sounds simple. I've been getting lost in trying to understand find command as in the undefined, yes I looked it up on google, "symbolic link".  Is that the filename? the icon?

sounds simple. I've been getting lost in trying to understand find command as in the undefined, yes I looked it up on google, "symbolic link".  Is that the filename? the icon?  -- I am interested in "find" to find a file not a charstring
Do you have any USB drives? Try plugging one in and see if "ls -l /dev/disk/by-path/" proves enlightening.
Try an Xubuntu LiveCD (I'd go with Xubuntu 11.10 personally).
I've never used xubuntu. Would I also feel confused?
Xubuntu is very similar to GNOME2's interface, and has the advantage that it will stay that way far into the future (whereas GNOME2 is pretty much dead, for any distribution).

LUbuntu is the lightest option when it comes to Ubuntu. It will run the fastest on old hardware with low RAM. Completely separate from that though, be prepared for Ubuntu (any variant) to not work properly on their hardware. There is a chance (though probably pretty low at this point) that the graphics drivers available for their hardware will be bad enough that it's slower than Windows, and there could be bugs that in the worst case prevent ...

And if you're trying to get people to use Ubuntu be honest about these types of problems. If they find out from experience that it's not quite as perfect as it was advertised to them it could seriously put them off Ubuntu.
so you are telling me that natty is more likely to work than lubuntu. -- these are not really old computers with low ram. these are normal windows systems. Which get buggy.
